title: Tapestry of Vulcan with Net to Trap the Lovers
credit_line: Purchase: gift of the Mudge Foundation
provenance_text:
Mortlake Tapestry Factory, London, England. Charles-Auguste Goyon de Gac√© de Matignon [1647-1729], France. Philip Hiss, New York, NY, by 1910 until at least 1935 [1]. Edmund W. Mudge [1870-1949], Pittsburgh, PA; Mrs. Pauline Seely Mudge [1879-1958], Pittsburgh, PA, until 1958 [2]; bequest to National Cathedral, Washington, D.C, by 1958 [3]; (French and Company, New York, NY, by May 14, 1958) [4]; purchased by Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, 1958. 
NOTES: [1] This name has also been recorded as "Hess", however the name has been recorded in the November 1910 Metropolitan Museum Bulletin as "Hiss", when this tapestry and two others in this series are sent on loan to the Metropolitan. In the 1935 printing of Helen Churchill Candee's "The Tapestry Book", this work is again recorded as being in the collection of Philip Hiss on pages 163-169. [2] Information from donor file on Mudge Foundation, letter from Protestant Episcopal Cathedral Foundation of the District of Columbia, dated May 26, 1958. [3] See curatorial file for correspondence between the National Cathedral,  French and Company, and the Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute. [4] Information from donor file on Mudge Foundation, copy of Bill of Sale from Protestant Episcopal Cathedral Foundation of the District of Columbia, dated May 14, 1958, in which the tapestry is listed as being in the custody of French and Company.
